noun.description: A formal examination of evidence before a judge, and typically before a jury, in order to decide guilt in a case of criminal or civil proceedings.
examples: the newspaper accounts of the trial
the editor was summoned to stand trial for libel

noun.description: A test of the performance, qualities, or suitability of someone or something.
examples: clinical trials must establish whether the new hip replacements are working

noun.description: A person, thing, or situation that tests a person's endurance or forbearance.
examples: the trials and tribulations of married life

verb.description: Test (something, especially a new product) to assess its suitability or performance.
examples: all seeds are carefully trialed in a variety of growing conditions

verb.description: (of a horse, dog, or other animal) compete in trials.

phrases: The set-up of the court is different from that for adults so the youth on trial feels more a part of the process.
At most, he may wind up on trial in a real court rather than merely in the press.
The court acquitted six of the defendants, while the soldiers on trial were all cashiered.
Though the press spinners are not on trial in Court 73, there are plenty who think they should be.
The six celebrity housemates have been on trial in the court of public popularity all week.
origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from Anglo-Norman French, or from medieval Latin triallum. The verb dates from the 1980s.
